<[silence:3400ms]>
Lonely worlds. Weather without stars.

<[silence:2400ms]>
"Rogue planet" means a planet drifting alone—no sun to orbit, no system to call home.

<[silence:1200ms]>
Imagine a marble rolling in the dark.
No sunlight warms it.
No seasons mark time.
Yet its weather rages on.

<[silence:2400ms]>
Heat comes from within.
Crushed by gravity, its core stays molten for billions of years—like a buried campfire under snow.
Volcanoes erupt into blackness,
spewing molten rock that freezes midair,
forming glass rain.

<[silence:1200ms]>
Winds howl at thousands of kilometers per hour.
No mountains slow them.
No oceans absorb their fury.
Just endless storms,
whipping frozen ammonia and iron dust
into cyclones wider than Earth.

<[silence:2400ms]>
Some rogues glow faintly—infared embers in the void.
Telescopes catch their heat signatures,
like spotting a lukewarm coin lost in a football field.

<[silence:1200ms]>
Three related subjects are diamond rain planets, brown dwarf atmospheres, and how life survives darkness.
